instruction: Given two strings, find the longest common subsequence between them. A subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, “ace” and “ae” are subsequences of “abcde” but “aec” and “cba” are not. The longest common subsequence (LCS) between two strings is the longest subsequence that is common to both strings. For example, if the two strings are “ABCDGH” and “AEDFHR”, then the LCS is “ADH” with length 3. Please use Java to solve the above question.

Given an integer array nums, return all the triplets [nums[i], nums[j], nums[k]] such that i != j, i != k, and j != k, and nums[i] + nums[j] + nums[k] == 0.

Notice that the solution set must not contain duplicate triplets.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [-1,0,1,2,-1,-4]
Output: [[-1,-1,2],[-1,0,1]]
Explanation: 
nums[0] + nums[1] + nums[2] = (-1) + 0 + 1 = 0.
nums[1] + nums[2] + nums[4] = 0 + 1 + (-1) = 0.
nums[0] + nums[3] + nums[4] = (-1) + 2 + (-1) = 0.
The distinct triplets are [-1,0,1] and [-1,-1,2].
Notice that the order of the output and the order of the triplets does not matter.

The study found that the 12-18 year old population was most likely to identify as "Jewish". In contrast, the youngest generation (18-26 year olds) was found to be the least likely to identify as Jewish, yet the most religious (for example, praying at least once a day). The researchers concluded that younger Jews are losing their Jewish culture and becoming more assimilated than their predecessors.
As it currently stands, our Jewish tradition does not include an institution that helps provide meaningful Jewish life and culture to younger generations. While there are plenty of programs and services dedicated to helping the youth connect with Judaism and Jewish community, we don’t have a program focused on helping young adults connect with their inner Jew.
This is where Project Makom comes in. We at Makom want to ensure that 18 year olds become 70 year olds who are able to live rich and vibrant Jewish lives with more meaning and joy, and not less. We want to see young Israelis grow and flourish into adulthood without the risk of feeling left in the cold when it comes to the important issue of being a part of something bigger.
I had originally envisioned Makom as an organization led by a few young (20 something) professionals in the community that would meet young adults in an informal and organic way, where people could simply share their journey as Jews and as Israelis. However, I was encouraged to open the organization to the entire community in hopes of making this work a communal undertaking.
To that end, I recently spoke at a meeting of an organization in Los Angeles that I am involved with and which does a lot of community education in Jewish circles. I told them that Makom is designed specifically for individuals who are searching for more meaning to their lives, and who are willing to take part in a serious spiritual journey that involves some amount of discomfort and struggle mixed in among the ecstasy.
Their response to this idea was a resounding “Amen”.
Those who volunteered to come with me to the 29 hour fast I attended this week were a mix of secular, religious Jews, and the non-Jewish spouses of participants in this fast. We discussed and reflected on a variety of topics that were not just “Jewish”, and yet the conversation naturally became quite Jewish. We discussed what it felt like to confront existential questions that were meaningful and engaging, and how this kind of spiritual work can be an important part of one’s life. We talked about how Jewish tradition was not just a set of rules, but a set of spiritual tools that are there for us to utilize in ways which feel right within our own contexts.
Several volunteers also expressed a desire to continue our conversations outside of our gatherings, and that a large part of why they are volunteering is to further that aspect of the project.
To this end, we have launched the Makom Forum, a private Facebook group for the volunteers and participants of Project Makom events to continue their conversation. The group is set up to be a discussion zone, not a lecture forum, where people can ask questions, or speak to their own experience.
To become a part of this forum, please contact me directly, and I would be happy to review your application.
I am looking forward to hearing from you and am hoping to grow our little community to include more like-minded individuals.

The aim of this assignment is to explore your point of view of controversial issues, to formulate an opinion and to support your viewpoint with valid facts and reasonable conclusions and to demonstrate your argumentation skills
Assignment Topic: You are asked to write an opinion piece on a controversial topic that you feel strongly about. What are some of the arguments for and against your position? How do you respond to these arguments? What are some of the potential consequences of your position? How does this issue affect people's lives?
Discipline: English Language and Linguistics / Semantics 1
Credit value: 5ECTS
Final degree mark: 10%
Purpose / Aims: The aim of this assignment is to explore your point of view of controversial issues, to formulate an opinion and to support your viewpoint with valid facts and reasonable conclusions and to demonstrate your argumentation skills.
Due Date: 22:59, Monday 17th November 2014
This assignment encourages students to write a well-structured and coherent argument in response to a specific topic and in response to counter arguments. The topics for this assignment is very broad and topics can be found on almost any major political, economic, cultural, sports or entertainment topic that you would find in newspapers, magazines or on the Internet. In addition, many major political and religious debates have become hot topics in recent years.
It will take a lot of time and effort to write such a paper and it should reflect a high level of your skills in academic writing. You will need to do research into the arguments of both sides and into the consequences of your positions. If you are unsure how to start, you can consult the following resources:
• http://www.wikihow.com/Write-an-Argumentative-Essay
• http://www.clackamas.edu/homepage/home/writing/arg.htm
An important element of this assignment is that you must be able to demonstrate effective persuasion skills and the ability to present and refute opposing viewpoints in a structured and logical way.
Academic requirements: (You are requested to use the attached “Template for opinion essay” as a guideline for this document.)
• You are asked to conduct independent research and find a topic of your interest to address a controversial issue. The topic you choose may relate to an aspect in the real world that you feel strongly about or you may choose to write about a controversial phenomenon in language or linguistics that interests you.
• You should address the topic in a way that it reflects your own views. You are encouraged to explore all views of the issue.
• Your writing should clearly express your view and a logical refutation of opposing viewpoints.
• The topic must be debatable or controversial and you must argue a point of view.
• Make sure that the facts you cite are accurate and that you cite your sources correctly. You are not allowed to cite Wikipedia or similar sources, since it cannot provide accurate, reliable and relevant information.
• The topic of your essay must be within the course scope and topic selection must be done personally by yourself.
Your paper must be in the form of an opinion piece and should satisfy the following requirements:
• You should have a strong position, i.e. the position that you are going to take must be clearly communicated to the reader.
• You should be able to discuss the topic from different perspectives and provide evidence in support of your opinion.
• You should be aware of counter-claims and the arguments that are made against your opinion/claim.
• You should demonstrate to the reader that you have thoroughly prepared the topic and clearly explained the main points of the issue in an organized and clear manner.
• You must use the appropriate terminology when referring to language rules, linguistic theories or research-related concepts. You must also use appropriate academic writing in scientific style.
Style requirements:
• You are asked to write in English using a direct and clear style.
• Opinions can be supported with personal experiences, relevant examples, and anecdotes from your life.
• You must refrain from using slang and casual language.
• You should be using logical arguments with explanations and proofs of your stance and you should be able to formulate your claims in different ways. You should also be able to develop a strong position by presenting convincing evidence of the arguments you present.
• You must write a fully structured essay with relevant paragraphs in accordance to the topic.
• Your paper should be composed in an academic style and in a formal and correct language.
• You should avoid colloquialism, informal and inappropriate words and language registers/styles.
• Your paper must include in-text referencing to show that you have used appropriate resources for your paper.
• You must support your claims and arguments with credible sources.
• It is important that you correctly cite ALL sources in your paper, whether they are direct quotations, summaries, examples or paraphrases.
• You should be able to use paraphrasing and quotation effectively to emphasise your point.
• It is necessary that you present an opinion piece and that you support your opinion. You must be able to express your views clearly and confidently with justifications.
• Do not summarise. Simply paraphrase.
• Follow the instructions about citation that are posted on http://www.kent.ac.uk/.
Note: The following online resources are only suggested and may help you in completing your assignment.
http://www.wikihow.com/Write-an-ArgumentativeEssay
http://www.clackamas.edu/homepage/home/writing/arg.htm
http://www.scribd.com/doc/133569657/Outline-forArgument-Essay
http://study.com/academy/lesson/outlining-an-argumentativepaper-lesson-quiz.html
http://www.uop.edu/academic-excellence/student-resources/studentlearning-centre/writing-service/essays/argumentative-essay
Pre-assignment briefing form
To: all course tutors
Please note that students are required to produce a paper in the form of an opinion essay, following the guidelines indicated in this document.
Students must follow academic writing conventions; in particular, academic referencing must be done in the way indicated at the bottom of this form.
It is essential that students must cite sources for all information that isn't common knowledge.
The use of internet sources is recommended provided it is clearly referenced to the original source. The use of Wikipedia or similar sources is not acceptable.
The final assessment for this course will be an opinion essay to be submitted online (word document, open MS word document).
We expect that the final product would consist of 2000 words with 1 inch margins, 12pt font, and references according to the Chicago Manual of Style.
The opinion essay is expected to follow the structure of an academic argument paper as indicated below:
An introductory paragraph (4-5 sentences). The purpose of the introduction is to briefly explain the topic, point of view, and central claims.
Paragraph 1: Thesis sentence with 2 topic sentences and some evidence (at least 2 sentences total)
Paragraph 2: 2 topic sentences and some evidence (at least 2 sentences total)
Paragraph 4: Thesis statement with 2 supporting points, each point in a separate paragraph
The paper should consist of an even number of paragraphs: 2+2+2+2=10. The length of each paragraph is not important – just make it long enough to convey the main idea without going too far beyond the main idea.
There should be a final paragraph that summarizes your thesis and includes a counter-argument. This is not an optional addition to the thesis – it is necessary that all papers will have a final paragraph that summarizes the thesis and offers a possible answer to a counter-argument.
The paper should contain a list of references – see below.
The paper should follow the Chicago Manual of Style format for academic writing. If you have any questions, you are welcome to read the online resources:
The Chicago Manual of Style Guide: http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/qa_faq.html
The Chicago Manual of Style, University of Chicago Press (cited hereafter as CMS): http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/tools_citationguide.html
